Award.AwardTitle: Laser-based Fabrication of Metal Nanocomposite on Flexible Substrate for Flexible Electronics with Enhanced Durability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a study on a laser-based fabrication process to fabricate metal nanocomposites onto flexible substrates. The research objective is to fundamentally understand laser-material interactions and materials' responses during the laser-based metal nanocomposite fabrication process, and mechanical and electrical properties of the fabricated metal nanocomposites. The goal is to establish the metal nanocomposite (fabricated through the laser-based process) processing-structure-property relations. Research work to be performed includes time-resolved measurements on the metal nanocomposite fabrication process, physics-based modeling, characterization of fabricated metal nanocomposite structures through scanning electron microscopy and other techniques, and measurements of the metal nanocomposites' mechanical and electrical properties.

The research is expected to provide an improved understanding of laser-material interactions and materials' responses during the laser-based metal nanocomposite fabrication process onto flexible substrates, and the metal nanocomposites' mechanical and electrical properties. It is expected that with suitable manufacturing process conditions, the nanocomposites may potentially enhance the durability and reliability of metallic components of flexible electronics, which may potentially have a broad impact on many applications of flexible electronics. This research on laser-based fabrication of metal nanocomposites provides a good opportunity for graduate student training, and some materials relevant to this research will be included in a graduate-level class taught by the principal investigator. It is expected that research results will be disseminated through approaches such as research papers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

This project involves research on laser-based fabrication of metal nanocomposites onto flexible substrates. The fabrication process typically involves the preparation of suspension for carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and metal nanoparticles (NPs), the dispensing of the suspension onto a polymer substrate and laser sintering of the dispensed mixture of CNTs and NPs to fabricate CNT-metal composite thin film onto the polymer substrate.

1. Intellectual Merit

This research has improved our understanding of: (i) laser-material interactions and material responses during the process of laser-based metal nanocomposite fabrication onto flexible substrates, and (ii) the structures, mechanical and electrical properties of the metal nanocomposites fabricated. Some major discoveries under the conditions studied and for the measured, characterized or tested samples or cases are very briefly summarized below.

The research work performed since the start of this project has shown that under the conditions studied and for the samples measured or tested, overall the laser-sintered CNT-metal (such as silver) composite films can have better mechanical properties, such as longer bending-fatigue lives, than similar laser-sintered metal films on a flexible substrate (such as polyimide) fabricated under similar conditions, without obviously degraded electrical conductivity (the conductivity may even be slightly better under certain conditions). Structure characterizations conducted provide supporting evidence that a significant amount of Ag-C chemical bonds is unlikely to exist at the CNT-silver interfaces in the characterized CNT-silver composite.  At the interface between a CNT-silver composite film and a polyimide substrate, interface roughness is observed, and it is expected that mechanical interlocking is likely to play an important role in the film-substrate adhesion. The characterizations conducted do not show a significant diffusion of silver into the polyimide substrate, but suggest that chemical reactions have likely occurred at around the interface between a CNT-silver composite film and a polyimide substrate.  

In-situ time-resolved temperature measurements through fast pyrometry during laser sintering of CNT and silver NP mixtures show that for continuous-wave (CW) laser sintering at a certain laser power, the peak temperature (in time) for the measurement spot does not change very significantly under a wide range of laser-spot traveling speeds studied, while the target surface melt lifetime determined from the temperature measurement obviously decreases. The measured surface temperature histories under several laser-spot speeds are similar for laser sintering of silver NPs and for laser sintering of a CNT-silver NP mixture (with a certain CNT weight percentage). For laser sintering of CNT and silver NP mixtures using ~200-ns laser pulses, the temperature measurements for stationary laser-spot sintering show that at a laser pulse repetition rate of 25 kHz, the measured surface temperature does not show an obvious thermal accumulation effect between adjacent laser pulses, while under a higher laser pulse repetition rate of 100 kHz, obvious thermal accumulation is observed. This leads to a much longer melt lifetime for 100-kHz laser pulses than that for 25-kHz laser pulses, under about the same laser sintering time and average laser power studied. The electrical resistivity of CNT-silver composites sintered by 100-kHz laser pulses can be much lower than that by 25-kHz laser pulses under about the same laser spot speed and average laser power.  

Molecular dynamics (MD) modeling work was performed to reveal the coalition process of metal NPs near a CNT and their interaction with the CNT under certain conditions at the atomic scale. MD modeling results under heating temperatures similar to the peak temperatures determined from fast pyrometry measurements do not show any obvious damage of the CNT structure. In our experiments (under the conditions experimentally investigated), coalition of silver nanoparticles (NPs) and the existence of CNTs were observed from some microscopic observations.    

 

2. Broader Impacts

The gained understanding from this research work may potentially benefit other relevant existing technologies (or help inspire new technologies) in manufacturing, materials synthesis and processing that involve things such as: carbon nanotube (CNT) ? metal composite synthesis, fabrication of metal thin films onto polymer substrates, and/or laser interactions with metal nanoparticles and/or CNTs. The nanocomposites fabricated by the laser-based process have a potential to help enhance the durability and reliability of metallic components of flexible electronics, which may possibly have a broad impact on many applications of flexible electronics. Since the beginning of this project, so far two journal papers were accepted and published, one conference paper was presented at the 2018 NAMRC conference (which received the 2018 NAMRI/SME Outstanding Paper Award), one related full patent application was filed, and another three journal papers are under preparation.  Three graduate students were ever supported by this project, while another ~3 undergraduate students were involved in work related to this project without being paid by this grant.  Some contents related to this project were introduced to students during some classes taught by the PI. 

 


Last Modified: 03/23/2019
Modified by: Benxin Wu
